description: A rather macabre fusion of biological matter and machine. Like a modern frankenstein you've used living tissue as a medium, some triffid organic components, various mutagens, some fresh blob to give it another kick at life, and a huge amount of electro-stimulators and stitchwork to create a barely-alive construct specifically engineered to synthesize fungicide from a pre-existing base and the air. For as long as it has power and a biological fungicidal base substance to start up it will continually replace a local atmospheric bubble with a fine toxic fungicidal mist. You've attached the roots of this myco-triffid construct to a metallic base that you can use to attach or remove the tower to or from any appropriate construct you wish. Unfortunately, once it has run out of its trigger synthesis base it cannot be turned off until it runs out of power.

A big cylindrical glass canister capped off on both sides with domes made from sheet metal and bolts holding things together. On one end there is a pipe and a collection of filters and pumps that filter in fresh air and pumps out the funigicidal gas the blob strain makes. This canister has been filled with the greenish blob, and the cables meant to shock them line the inside of the canister.

A greenish blob that has been modified to synthesize a gaseous fungicide. Unlike its darker counterpart it is mostly immobile and doesn't react to most things, leaving it on the same level of existence as a squishy rock or something. Giving it a small jolt of electricity stimulates it to release its fungicidal gas, and a lot of them together could make enough to be of use to you.
A 200L drum modified to have straps and things to allow wearing it as a backpack. Lots of storage for lots of encumberance. Its open top allows long items to stick out of it.
A 100L drum modified to have straps and things to allow wearing it as a backpack. Lots of storage for lots of encumberance. Its open top allows long items to stick out of it.

This is a full-body suit with a network of small fans and airflow tubes that run the airflow over the skin in order to cool the wearer off. It's powered by any medium-sized batteries that can fit into its battery compartment on the hip.  Use it to turn it on.

This is a full-body suit with a network of small fans and airflow tubes that run the airflow over the skin in order to cool the wearer off. It is currently on, and continually draining batteries. Use it to turn it off.
A small fan that's too small for many of the uses one would use a fan for, but if it were attached to your body and powered it would feel refeshingly cool and not bother you.
A small fan blade to be used in the making of a small fan. You'll need a lot for its intended use.

An electromagnetic refridgeration suit. It uses the magnetocaloric effect to cool down the water in ts closed loop tubing and then pumps the cold water throughout the flexible tubes that are in contact with the skin in order to cool the body off. It's powered by any medium-sized batteries that can fit into its battery compartment on the hip.  Use it to turn it on.

An electromagnetic refridgeration suit. It uses the magnetocaloric effect to cool down the water in ts closed loop tubing and then pumps the cold water throughout the flexible tubes that are in contact with the skin in order to cool the body off. It is currently on, and continually draining batteries. Use it to turn it off.

A more advanced electromagnetic refridgeration suit. This one is designed to cool the nitrogen in its closed loop system to a liquid state and pump it around to cool down the wearer. Use with caution in environments that don't have inhospitably hot conditions as it's likely to freeze the wearer if external temperatures aren't hot enough to compensate. Naturally, it uses the magnetocaloric effect to accomplish this. It's powered by any large-sized batteries that can fit into its battery compartment on the back.  Use it to turn it on.

A more advanced electromagnetic refridgeration suit. This one is designed to cool the nitrogen in its closed loop system to a liquid state and pump it around to cool down the wearer. Use with caution in environments that don't have inhospitably hot conditions as it's likely to freeze the wearer if external temperatures aren't hot enough to compensate. Naturally, it uses the magnetocaloric effect to accomplish this. It is currently on, and continually draining batteries. Use it to turn it off.

Gadolinium is a silvery-white metal when oxidation is removed. It is only slightly malleable and is a ductile rare-earth element. Gadolinium reacts with atmospheric oxygen or moisture slowly to form a black coating. Used in applications of the magnetocaloric effect.

Pressure swing adsorption (PSA) is a technology used to separate some gases from a mixture of gases under pressure according to the gas' molecular characteristics and affinity for an adsorbent material. It operates at near-ambient temperatures and differs significantly from cryogenic distillation techniques of gas separation. This one is small but specialized to extract nitrogen from the air. Best have a container handy when you do.
A simple gas canister for storing nitrogen. Not a whole lot of use for it in the apocalypse but perhaps you'll find a use for the nitrogen itself.
Nitrogen is the chemical element with the symbol N and atomic number 7. It has many uses and applications, but for now all you can think of using it for is liquid nitrogen for cooling.
